propositions.text: The story begins with the narrator receiving a phone call, signaling a potential life-altering event.
The phone call interrupts his solitary evening in a dimly lit study.
He reflects on his lack of premonition or ability to predict the future.
His father is critically ill, and the narrator fears losing him and facing life alone at twenty-eight, being an only child whose mother passed away two years prior.
He is unable to sleep soundly after returning home before dawn.
The persistent ringing of the phone makes him wish it would stop.
Even the dog, Olson, senses the gravity of the call.
Olson is described as an unusual dog that stares intently at people, unlike other dogs.
The narrator speculates that Olson might also perceive something unsettling.
Despite its strangeness, Olson is the narrator's dog, trusted friend, and beloved companion.
The narrator finally answers the phone on the seventh ring.
The call is from a nurse at Mercy Hospital, informing him of his father's rapidly deteriorating condition and advising him to come immediately.
As he hangs up, Olson rests his head on his lap, groaning softly and nudging his hand without wagging its tail.
The narrator experiences a moment of paralysis, unable to think or act.
The silence of the house feels oppressive.
He then calls Sasha Guldo to drive him to the hospital.
Sasha, a night radio host, is likely asleep at this early hour, and the narrator feels guilty about waking her.
Like Olson, Sasha is a friend he can rely on, and she drives much better than a dog.
Sasha answers on the second ring, sounding alert and stating, 'Chris, I'm sorry.'
He wonders if she also sensed the ominous news from the phone's ring.
He suppresses thoughts of what might happen, clinging to the hope that his father is still alive and that the doctors might be mistaken.
He believes in miracles, considering his own survival to twenty-eight years a miracle, despite how others might perceive his life as a curse.
Sasha promises to arrive in five minutes.
Walking to the hospital now would be too conspicuous and risky.
He asks her to be careful driving and says he needs about ten minutes to prepare.
They exchange "I love yous."
The narrator arrives at the funeral home, 'Kirk's Funeral Home,' a large Georgian-style building.
The drive is lined with pepper trees, which look different in daylight and at night.
The funeral home is situated on a three-acre hilltop, accessible via an overpass off Highway 1.
The trees lining the drive appear like mourners.
The narrator ascends the private road, noting landscape lights and the rustling of leaves.
No cars are parked along the drive, indicating no services are currently underway.
He usually walks or bikes, as he doesn't drive during the day and has trouble with headlights at night.
A full moon rises, and he appreciates its gentle, illuminating light.
At the center of a circular lawn at the top of the hill stands a concrete cast of Michelangelo's Pietà.
In the moonlight, the statue of Jesus' body and Mary appears luminous.
He recognizes it as a crude imitation that would look worse in daylight.
He acknowledges that such sculptures can offer solace to those grieving, highlighting humanity's ability to find hope.
He hesitates at the porch, uncertain of what lies ahead.
The funeral home, a two-story Georgian structure, would be charming elsewhere but feels out of place in Moon Bay.
The second floor, where Sandy lives, is dark.
The viewing room is on the first floor, with faint light visible through stained-glass windows.
He rings the doorbell.
Sandy Kirk emerges from the hallway, opening the door and appearing surprised to see him.
Sandy expresses condolences for his father's passing.
He assures the narrator that his father was treated with great care.
Sandy recounts taking a twentieth-century poetry class taught by the narrator's father, developing a deep appreciation for poets like Eliot, Pound, and Auden.
He mentions that Wallace Stevens, Donald Justice, and Louise Glück were his father's personal favorites.
Sandy turns off the lights in the foyer and porch out of consideration.
He acknowledges the narrator's grief but adds that his father is no longer suffering.
The narrator asks to see his father, regretting not having done so at the hospital.
Sandy's expression suggests a hidden turmoil beneath his calm demeanor.
He apologetically states that arrangements have already been made.
The narrator directly asks if his father has been cremated.
Sandy, unaccustomed to such bluntness, confirms that the deceased has been transferred for cremation.
The narrator questions the speed of the process.
Sandy implies that delays are not advisable in his profession.
The narrator feels ashamed, realizing Sandy has lied.
He looks down at the floor, unable to meet Sandy's gaze.
Sandy misinterprets his shame as sadness and offers a comforting pat on the shoulder.
Sandy admits his inadequacy in comforting the bereaved.
The narrator states he will be alright and leaves to avoid further impulse actions.
Sandy remarks that he avoids clichés, preferring to say something specific to the narrator.
The narrator thanks Sandy and apologizes for the disturbance.
Sandy wishes the narrator had called earlier, implying he could have delayed the cremation.
The narrator retreats and turns away from Sandy.
Sandy asks about funeral arrangements.
The narrator promises to inform him tomorrow.
Sandy asks if he is alright, to which the narrator replies he is okay, in a monotone voice.
The narrator walks away from the funeral home, towards the Pietà sculpture.
The mica in the sculpture makes the Virgin Mary's face shine under the moonlight.
He resists the urge to look back, sure that Sandy is watching.
He walks down the drive, the trees whispering like they are conversing.
The temperature drops to around sixty degrees Fahrenheit.
A sea breeze, purified by its journey, carries a faint salty scent.
He dares to look back only after a long distance down the private road.
He sees only the sharp roofline and chimney shadows against the starry sky.
He moves from the asphalt to the grass and begins to climb uphill, now under the shade of trees.
The moon appears woven into the pepper trees' branches.
The funeral home's circular driveway and the Pietà statue come back into view.
Sandy has gone inside, and the main door is closed.
The narrator circles behind the house, using trees and bushes for cover.
The backyard features a large balcony, a seventy-foot swimming pool, a Spanish-style courtyard, and a rose garden, hidden from public view.
Moon Bay has two funeral homes for its population, with Kirk's handling most of the business.
Death is a profitable business for Sandy.
He imagines the daytime view from the courtyard, with rolling hills and scattered oak trees.
Seeing no one in the lit window, he crosses the courtyard.
The moonlight shines on the dark pool water.
The house is adjacent to an L-shaped garage containing two hearses, Sandy's car, and the crematorium.
He sneaks to the corner of the garage, moving along the shorter side, hidden by eucalyptus trees.
The air is filled with the herbal scent of trees, and fallen leaves crunch underfoot.
He knows this area well, having explored the town at night and encountered unsettling discoveries.
The dim light ahead indicates the crematorium window.
He anticipates seeing something gruesome, recalling a similar childhood experience.
Fifteen years ago, he and his friend Bobby Hallowell, driven by morbid curiosity, broke into the funeral home.
They sought something ugly, terrifying, and scary, perhaps a pile of skulls or a secret laboratory.
They might have expected to encounter mythical creatures like Cthulhu or Yog-Sothoth in the rose garden, having read Lovecraft.
Bobby called them strange kids; the narrator felt they were just like other boys, but Bobby encouraged embracing their uniqueness.
One October night, they discovered the crematorium window by chance, attracted by a flickering light.
Unable to see through the high window, they moved a wooden bench from the courtyard.
They peered inside, seeing Frank Kirk and his assistant working, as the blinds were left open.
He remembers the risk of blindness but was driven by the desire to share the moment with Bobby.
They saw a stretcher with an old man's body, covered by a sheet, revealing a gruesome face.
The man's appearance suggested a prolonged illness rather than a violent death.
Even if they knew him, his current state was terrifying.
The most striking feature was his one open eye, filled with blood, making him look blind but staring directly at them.
They watched Frank and his assistant prepare the incinerator, noting the heat in the room.
Despite the mild October night, they shivered and wondered why they didn't exhale visible breath.
The cremation workers pulled back the sheet, revealing the horrifying effects of age and illness.
As the body was placed into a cardboard box and pushed into the blue flames of the incinerator, the narrator and Bobby clutched each other, fearing they might be pulled in.
Frank Kirk closed the furnace door, the sound echoing through them.
They returned the bench and fled, hiding at the high school's empty football stadium.
They drank cola and ate chips, exclaiming how 'cool' the experience was, comparing it to other thrilling but ultimately mundane events.
They reflect on how thirteen-year-olds can be so daring.
The adventure solidified their friendship, making it deeper and more complex.
The narrator felt Bobby became more mysterious, and he likely appeared the same to Bobby.
He realized that night was merely a prelude to a more profound experience in December.
Now, fifteen years later, he is back at the same window, the blinds still the same.
He can see Sandy Kirk and his assistant working near the 'Power Pak II' cremation system.
They are wearing masks, gloves, and disposable aprons.
A nylon body bag lies on a gurney, its zipper down, containing a dead man, presumably the homeless man who will be cremated instead of his father.
The man's face is disfigured, and his eyes are missing, replaced by bloody sockets.
This horror far surpasses the bloody eye of the old man they saw as children, representing the cruelty of man rather than nature.
He recalls returning to the crematorium window with Bobby in the following months, associating the scent of eucalyptus with death.
Frank Kirk cremated only three of the fourteen funerals in October; the rest were embalmed for traditional burial.
They lamented the lack of a window in the embalming room, which was located in the basement.
The narrator was secretly relieved they couldn't observe the embalming.
Frank likely performed embalming during the day and cremation at night.
The old incinerator was more primitive than the 'Power Pak II,' and smoke escaped the chimney.
Frank chose night cremation to spare families the sight of their loved ones turning into smoke.
Bobby's father, Anson, was the editor of the Moon Bay Gazette, providing them with news of accidental and natural deaths.
They would rush to the funeral home after sunset, waiting by the crematorium window.
Mr. Gales, the sixty-year-old president of National First Bank, died of a heart attack in late October, and they watched him being cremated.
Henry Ames, a carpenter, fell from a roof and broke his neck in November. He was cremated, but they missed the process as the blinds were closed.
In December, they witnessed the cremation of Roby Eakins, a thirty-year-old librarian and mother of a five-year-old son.
She lay on the gurney, covered by a sheet, appearing beautiful and ethereal.
They felt a sense of awe and respect, without any inappropriate thoughts.
Her death was sudden, caused by a ruptured cerebral artery.
Her eyes were closed, and her lips were slightly upturned, suggesting a peaceful dream.
As the sheet was lifted, they saw her slender, perfectly proportioned body, a beauty beyond carnal attraction.
She looked young and timeless.
The cremation personnel handled her body with gentleness and reverence.
Frank Kirk removed his gloves and wiped his eyes, not from sweat.
Unlike previous times, Frank and his assistant were silent during the cremation.
The narrator and Bobby were also speechless.
They returned the bench, left the funeral home quietly, and rode their bikes to the beach.
The vast, deserted beach was illuminated by city lights in the distance and the dark ocean before them.
The gentle waves broke softly on the shore.
The narrator thought of Christmas approaching and the orphaned son, Danny, and his father, Tom.
Bobby suggested they go swimming.
Despite the mild weather, the December sea was cold.
They swam out a considerable distance, then turned north, parallel to the shore.
They were skilled swimmers but became careless due to the illusion of warmth from physical exertion.
The cold water seeped in, and they never reached a comfortable temperature.
They failed to swim back to shore and instead swam south, still far from land.
Their limbs grew heavy, and they experienced stomach cramps.
The waves felt more formidable on the return journey.
They stayed close, relying on their friendship as their only comfort.
Upon reaching the shore, they were exhausted, nauseated, and shivering violently.
They were too cold to even recall the heat of the crematorium.
They rode their bikes home and fell asleep immediately.
They never returned to the crematorium window or spoke of Roby Eakins again.
Their friendship remained strong, based on a willingness to sacrifice for each other.
The narrator muses on the surreal nature of reality, suggesting that abstract concepts like love, friendship, and loneliness are more real than physical experiences.
The narrator returns to the crematorium window, confirming the gruesome reality of the scene.
A hitchhiker was brutally beaten to death and his eyes were gouged out.
He questions the motive for removing the eyes, even if the body was intended as a swap for his father's.
He recalls the description of the large, rough man with a cold demeanor and a voice like rusty iron, who might take pleasure in others' suffering.
As Sandy and his assistant push the gurney towards the furnace, the phone rings.
Feeling guilty, the narrator retreats from the window.
When he looks back, Sandy, now unmasked, is on the phone, his tone shifting from confusion to alarm to rage.
Sandy slams the receiver down, the sound presumably deafening whoever is on the other end.
Sandy speaks urgently to his assistant, Jesse Pynne, and the narrator thinks he hears his name mentioned.
Jesse, described with a thin face, red hair, and amber eyes, begins to zip up the body bag.
The narrator notices a shoulder holster under Sandy's suit jacket.
Sandy shouts at Jesse and gestures towards the window.
The narrator believes he has not been seen but decides to flee based on a pessimistic intuition.
He escapes through the gap between the garage and the eucalyptus trees, the scent of death in the air.
The crunch of dead leaves underfoot is masked by the wind in the trees and the sound of the ocean.
He suspects the phone call was from a hospital orderly who found his father's wallet in the suitcase, realizing the body swap.
This call would alert Sandy that the narrator's presence at the door was more than just a condolence visit.
He believes Sandy and Jesse will come out to check if he is still nearby.
He reaches the backyard and decides against crossing the courtyard, deeming the risk of returning to the house and driveway too great.
He runs across the lawn to the rose garden behind the funeral home.
The garden is a series of tiered platforms with trellises, arbors, and winding paths.
Roses are in full bloom, with dark flowers appearing black in the moonlight, and white flowers resembling baby heads.
He hears voices and sees two flashlight beams, followed by more, revealing a search party.
Sandy is holding a flashlight and presumably a gun.
The narrator is surprised by the speed and number of the searchers, who are systematically scanning the area.
He feels like he's in a waking nightmare, pursued by faceless figures through a maze.
He races down the five-tiered garden, fearing a fall.
The trellises and arbors resemble hollowed-out ruins, with thorny vines seeming to twist with life.
His heart pounds, and the sky seems to be falling.
He reaches the end of the garden and collides with a seven-foot-tall iron fence.
He slides down the fence, unharmed but with thorns in his temple.
The strong scent of roses has become a pungent odor, mixed with his sunscreen and sweat.
He has an absurd thought that the pursuers can track him by scent, but they are currently downwind.
He watches the search party ascend the garden tiers.
The searchlights distort the trellises into shapes resembling dinosaur bones.
Despite the garden offering more hiding places than the lawn, the searchers are moving faster.
He carefully climbs over the fence into a wide, dark valley with rolling hills and scattered oak trees.
The grass, recently grown from winter rains, is knee-high.
He knows Sandy's group will search every inch of the area and must escape the flashlight beams.
He runs further from the city, realizing his vulnerability in the wilderness.
He is grateful for the tall grass, which will hide his tracks, unlike dry grass that would show a clear path.
He reaches a dense thicket of shrubs and tall grass, followed by a ten-foot-wide natural drainage ditch.

main_topics: The immediate aftermath of a critical phone call
A visit to a funeral home and the confrontation with deception
Recollections of childhood experiences and friendships
Discovery of a horrifying crime and subsequent escape
hierarchy.structure: The document is structured chronologically, moving from the narrator's immediate emotional state to his actions and reflections. It incorporates flashbacks to childhood experiences, which are central to understanding his present motivations and fears. The narrative builds tension as the narrator uncovers a crime and then becomes a fugitive.
